subject: Re: [junit] displaying multiple errors from the same condition
msgSnippet: ... Only since Java 5 though; some of us still have to produce code which works with earlier versions of Java! -- ... [Non-text portions of this message have
messageBody:
On 30/11/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Chris Dollin wrote:
> > On Tuesday 29 November 2005 18:32, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >
> > > The short answer: there is a way to make JUnit do this, but many of
> us
> > > don't like to do it that way. For a test like this, I might do the
> > > following:
> > >
> > > List failedUrls = new ArrayList();
> > > foreach (URL url : urlsToTest) {
> > > if (failed(url)) {
> > > failedUrls.add(url);
> > > }
> > > }
> > > assertTrue(failedUrls.isEmpty());
> >
> > I would use
> >
> > assertEquals( new ArrayList(), failedUrls );
> >
> > [and might well have a constant `emptyList` around], on the grounds
> > that when the Unfortunate Event of test failure occurs the default
> > failure message of assertEquals will tell me which URLs failed.
>
> :)
>
> Everyone thinks I'm a little slow today.
>
> By the way, the "emptyList" constant already exists:
> Collections.EMPTY_LIST.


Only since Java 5 though; some of us still have to produce code which works
with earlier versions of Java!

--
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
